Crime_Name: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act Violation
Application_Facts: Applicant claimed refugee status due to fear of persecution from an abusive former partner in Namibia
Misrepresentation_Element: Inconsistencies in testimony regarding police interactions
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review challenging credibility and state protection findings
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Inconsistencies in applicant's testimony
Credibility_Assessment: Board found applicant's testimony inconsistent, credibility rejected
Relief_Sought: Overturn of Board's negative decision, recognition as refugee
Remedy_Sought: Judicial review of Board's decision
Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness standard in assessing state protection and credibility
Decision_Rationale: Board's credibility findings and state protection analysis were reasonable and supported by evidence

Application_Facts: Applicant provided evidence of domestic violence in Canada and fear of her cousin.
Procedural_Issue: Board failed to address the applicant's sur place claim despite evidence supporting it.
Evidence_Used: Evidence of domestic violence in Canada, fear of cousin
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to analyze sur place claim even though evidence was presented
Decision_Outcome: Board dismissed the claim without addressing the sur place aspect
Outcome: Judicial review allowed; decision set aside
Relief_Sought: Recognition of refugee status based on persecution in Turkey and domestic violence in Canada
Remedy_Sought: Redetermination by the Board
Legal_Standard_Applied: The Board must examine sur place refugee claims if supported by evidence
Decision_Rationale: Failure to consider sur place claim constitutes a reviewable error

Victim_Status: Refugee claimant, survivor of sexual assault in Canada
Aggravating_Factors: Assault occurred after fleeing persecution in home country
Risk_Assessment: Ongoing risk from cousin in Canada
Risk_Nature: Threat of further abuse or retaliation
Targeted_Victimization: Yes – based on familial and gender-based dynamics
Evidence_Sufficiency: Sufficient evidence presented but not analyzed
Evidence_Type: Testimonial evidence of abuse, fear of cousin
Evidence_Credibility: Not properly assessed due to procedural oversight
Credibility_Assessment: Negative inferences drawn for not reporting abuse, but sur place claim ignored
Legal_Provision: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), subsection 72(1)

Dispute_Type: Refugee protection claim involving personal safety
Legal_Issue: Failure to assess sur place refugee claim based on domestic violence
Evidence_Assessment: Inconsistencies noted (e.g., non-disclosure to family), but sur place evidence not evaluated
Decision_Outcome: Board rejected credibility and dismissed claim
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to establish well-founded fear; partially met but not recognized
Credibility_Factor: Non-disclosure used to discredit, but context not fully considered
Legal_Rule: Board must examine sur place claims when evidence supports them
Grounds_for_Claim: Fear of cousin, domestic violence in Canada
Outcome_on_Merits: Claim dismissed due to procedural failure
Key_Evidence_Considered: Allegations of abuse, relationship with cousin
Authority: Immigration and Refugee Board, Federal Court

Victim_Status: Refugee claimant facing threats in Canada
Aggravating_Factors: Threats made by relative in context of prior abuse
Criminality_Severity: High – credible threat of bodily harm
Risk_Assessment: Serious risk of physical harm from cousin
Risk_Nature: Continuing pattern of intimidation and violence
Evidence_Sufficiency: Evidence of threats and assault presented during hearing
Evidence_Type: Testimony about threats and assault by cousin
Evidence_Credibility: Not assessed due to Board’s omission
Credibility_Assessment: No analysis conducted on sur place claim
Legal_Provision: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, subsection 72(1)

Crime_Name: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act Violation
Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 96 and Section 97 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA)
Application_Facts: Applicant claimed fear of persecution by LTTE and Sri Lankan authorities due to Tamil ethnicity and alleged involvement with opposition groups.
Procedural_Issue: Credibility assessment, Internal Flight Alternative (IFA) determination
Evidence_Used: Testimony of applicant, country condition reports on Sri Lanka, evidence of risks for Tamils in certain regions
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Inconsistencies in testimony regarding agents of persecution
Credibility_Assessment: Board found inconsistencies in applicant's testimony; court found the credibility assessment to be erroneous
Outcome: Judicial review allowed; decision set aside
Relief_Sought: Recognition as a protected person under IRPA
Remedy_Sought: Redetermination of refugee claim by a different panel
Legal_Standard_Applied: Serious possibility of persecution, reasonableness of internal flight alternative
Decision_Rationale: Board erred in credibility analysis and IFA assessment given ongoing risks for Tamils in Sri Lanka
Authority_Responsible: Immigration and Refugee Board of Canada (IRB)

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of PRRA and H&C decisions
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicants' evidence was equivocal; credibility concerns due to prior inconsistencies
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Allegations of rape and trafficking without objective documentation
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 25 (H&C grounds), Section 113(a) (new evidence in PRRA)
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Fear of domestic violence and persecution by mother's former spouse
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of credible and objective evidence to support risk or hardship
Crimes.Application_Error: Insufficient substantiation of claims despite serious allegations
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness standard applied to administrative decisions
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: None explicitly ignored; officer required more substantiation
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Applicants must provide credible evidence of risk or hardship under IRPA
Crimes.Application_Factor: Use of false passports and prior credibility issues

Crimes.Crime_Name: Using forged documents to gain entry
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of PRRA and H&C decisions given lack of evidence
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Claims lacked credible evidence; applicants previously rejected for insufficient proof
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Alleged domestic violence without sufficient supporting documentation
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 25 (H&C exemptions), Section 113(a) (restriction on new evidence in PRRA)
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Fear of persecution due to domestic violence in Nigeria
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Failure to provide objective evidence of risk or hardship
Crimes.Proceeding_Type: Post-refusal PRRA and H&C applications followed by judicial review
Crimes.Application_Error: Inability to meet evidentiary burden despite humanitarian claims
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: No new compelling evidence presented post-refusal
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Requirement for credible, objective evidence under IRPA
Crimes.Application_Factor: Use of forged documents at entry and subsequent asylum claims
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Entry into Canada using forged British passports

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Refugee protection claim involving state protection assessment
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the RPD's decision on state protection was reasonable and adequately considered all evidence
Crimes.Outcome: RPD's decision found unreasonable and quashed
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant did not provide enough credible evidence to rebut presumption of state protection, though court found RPD failed in its duty to assess properly
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Evidence of systemic issues in Bolivia's protection mechanisms for domestic violence victims
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act – burden on claimant to rebut presumption of state protection
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Claimant fled domestic violence and alleged inadequate state protection in Bolivia
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Operational adequacy of state protection in Bolivia
Crimes.Application_Error: RPD failed to adequately assess operational adequacy despite available evidence
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness standard applied by Federal Court
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Significant evidence of systemic failures in Bolivia’s response to domestic violence
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Claimant must provide clear and convincing evidence to rebut presumption of state protection
Crimes.Application_Factor: Domestic violence, attempts to seek protection, lack of police response
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Application allowed, RPD decision quashed, remanded for reconsideration
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Misrepresentation in border or refugee documentation regarding basis of claim

Crimes.Sub_Crime_Type: Sexual and physical abuse within context of domestic violence
Crimes.Victim_Status: Female survivor of domestic abuse seeking refugee protection
Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Repeated abuse, failure of authorities to intervene, systemic underreporting and impunity
Crimes.Mitigating_Factors: None identified; focus on severity and state inaction
Crimes.Prior_Criminality: Pattern of abuse with no legal consequences for perpetrator
Crimes.Criminality_Severity: High – ongoing sexual and physical violence
Crimes.Risk_Assessment: High risk of continued harm due to lack of effective state protection
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Targeted victimization due to gender and relationship status
Crimes.Threat_Source: Intimate partner with history of violence and state complicity through inaction
Crimes.Targeted_Victimization: Yes – based on gender and domestic relationship
Crimes.Targeted_Individual: The applicant as a woman subjected to domestic violence
Crimes.Evidence_Sufficiency: Sufficient evidence presented but RPD failed to properly weigh it
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Personal testimony, country condition reports on domestic violence in Bolivia
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Credible evidence of abuse and ineffective police response
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant’s account largely accepted, but RPD focused on legislative progress over practice
Crimes.Sentencing_Issue: Not applicable – matter involves immigration protection, not criminal sentencing
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act – criteria for assessing state protection

Crimes.Sub_Crime_Type: Physical assault within domestic violence context
Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Repeated assaults, lack of police intervention, high rates of domestic violence
Crimes.Prior_Criminality: History of violent behavior by perpetrator without prosecution
Crimes.Risk_Assessment: Ongoing risk due to absence of enforcement mechanisms
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Non-random, targeted abuse rooted in gender inequality
Crimes.Threat_Source: Ex-partner enabled by lack of state accountability
Crimes.Targeted_Victimization: Yes – based on gender and domestic relationship
Crimes.Targeted_Individual: The applicant as a woman in an abusive relationship
Crimes.Evidence_Sufficiency: Strong evidence of repeated assaults and poor enforcement
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Personal testimony, country reports on domestic violence enforcement gaps
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant deemed credible; RPD did not give adequate weight to lived experience
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act – operational adequacy of state protection

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to Protect Victims of Domestic Violence
Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Refugee claim based on gender-based persecution and lack of state protection
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Involved: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, international human rights obligations
Crimes.Outcome: RPD decision set aside due to flawed state protection analysis
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Gender-based persecution due to domestic violence and lack of effective state response
Crimes.Legal_Framework: International refugee law, gender-based persecution principles, state duty to protect
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Remanded for reconsideration by differently constituted panel
Crimes.Institutional_Action: Inadequate police response and limited resources for domestic violence survivors
Crimes.Individual_Status_or_Claim: Refugee claimant fearing return due to prior abuse and lack of protection
Crimes.Targeted_Group: Female victims of intimate partner violence in Bolivia
Crimes.State_Protection_Assessment: Legislative framework exists but operational implementation is inadequate
Crimes.Risk_Factor: High prevalence of domestic violence, low reporting, lack of enforcement
Crimes.Credibility: Applicant’s testimony supported by objective country evidence
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act – burden and standard for rebutting state protection
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Systemic failure to protect women from domestic violence
Crimes.Perpetrator_Entity: Private actor (ex-partner) with state complicity through omission
Crimes.Victim_Basis: Gender and personal history of abuse

Violation_Type: Failure to meet refugee protection criteria under changed country conditions
Application_Facts: Applicants claimed refugee status based on past political persecution in Ukraine; Board found country conditions improved post-Orange Revolution; past mistreatment deemed 'abhorrent' but not 'atrocious'
Procedural_Issue: Allegation of procedural unfairness in the Board’s assessment
Evidence_Used: Country condition reports, evidence of political changes in Ukraine, documentation of past mistreatment
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient evidence to establish compelling reasons under §108(4) due to lack of severity in past persecution
Credibility_Assessment: Not explicitly challenged; focus was on changed circumstances rather than credibility
Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed; applicants remain non-refugees
Relief_Sought: Recognition as Convention refugees
Remedy_Sought: Judicial review of the Board’s decision
Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness, Procedural fairness
Decision_Rationale: Country conditions in Ukraine have fundamentally changed; no compelling reasons exist under IRPA §108(4) to maintain refugee status despite past persecution
Authority_Responsible: Immigration and Refugee Board (IRB), Federal Court

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review of refugee claim rejection
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Violation of natural justice principles or Charter rights in credibility assessment
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Negative credibility due to inconsistent statements and implausible explanations
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Authority of visa officers to assess Convention refugee claims overseas
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Refugee protection based on fear of persecution
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Credibility of the applicant
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Natural justice and procedural fairness
Crimes.Application_Factor: Overseas location of applicant affecting procedural rights

Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration Act - Credibility and truthfulness requirements
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant claimed persecution in Iraq with inconsistencies in details
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Alleged lack of procedural fairness in decision-making
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Visa officer authority over overseas applicants
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of credible, consistent evidence supporting persecution claim
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Found not credible due to contradictions and implausibility
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Refugee claim rejected; judicial review dismissed
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Overturn visa officer's rejection of refugee claim
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Judicial intervention based on procedural unfairness
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Visa officer acted within discretion and followed proper procedures
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Visa officer at Canadian diplomatic mission abroad

Application_Facts: Applicant failed to act within the 90-day period, did not demonstrate inability to act or instruct another person, and lacked a bona fide intention to request a decision. Evidence showed awareness of the NPAs but no action taken.
Procedural_Issue: Failure to meet deadline for requesting a decision on NPAs; application made after 90-day period
Evidence_Used: Evidence showed awareness of the NPAs but no action taken
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failed to demonstrate inability to act or bona fide intention to request a decision
Decision_Outcome: Application for extension of time dismissed
Outcome: Application dismissed, costs awarded to Respondent
Relief_Sought: Extension of time to request a decision of the Minister regarding the NPAs
Legal_Standard_Applied: (a) application within one year after 90-day period; (b) inability to act or bona fide intention; (c) just and equitable; (d) application made as soon as circumstances permitted
Decision_Rationale: Applicant does not meet criteria under subsection 129.2(4) of the Customs Act

Application_Facts: Applicant claimed persecution in Croatia due to Serbian origin and in Serbia by her father
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review of RPD decision
Evidence_Used: Evidence presented before the RPD regarding persecution claims
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of credible evidence to support ongoing threat
Credibility_Assessment: RPD found no credible threat in either country based on evidence and time elapsed
Decision_Outcome: RPD rejected the applicant's refugee claim
Relief_Sought: Recognition as a refugee and protection under IRPA
Remedy_Sought: Judicial review of RPD decision
Legal_Standard_Applied: Well-founded fear of persecution under IRPA
Decision_Rationale: RPD's decision was reasonable and adequately considered all evidence

Violation_Type: Claiming refugee status without meeting the criteria under IRPA
Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), Section 96 and Section 97
Application_Facts: Applicant claimed religious persecution in China due to participation in an underground church; alleged a raid on the church in Guangdong Province
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review of RPD decision on credibility and evidence assessment
Evidence_Used: Oral testimony by applicant, documentary evidence on religious conditions in Guangdong Province
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of corroborating evidence for church raid; absence of reported incidents of persecution against lay Christians
Credibility_Assessment: RPD found applicant's testimony about the church raid not credible
Decision_Outcome: RPD rejected refugee claim; Federal Court dismissed judicial review application
Relief_Sought: Recognition as a Convention refugee or person in need of protection
Remedy_Sought: Judicial review of RPD decision
Legal_Standard_Applied: Well-founded fear of persecution on grounds of religion; need to demonstrate lack of state protection
Decision_Rationale: RPD's conclusion was reasonable based on documentary evidence indicating religious freedom for lay Christians in Guangdong; applicant's testimony lacked credibility
Authority_Responsible: Refugee Protection Division (RPD), Federal Court of Canada

Violation_Type: Failure to consider contradictory evidence in refugee claim assessment
Application_Facts: Principal Applicant is a homosexual Mexican citizen who faced threats and assaults after criticizing a group; claimed fear of police due to corruption and discrimination against homosexuals
Claimant_Status: Homosexual Mexican citizen seeking refugee status
Procedural_Issue: Board failed to address evidence contrary to its finding on state protection availability
Evidence_Used: Availability of protective agencies in Mexico
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient consideration of evidence regarding effectiveness of police protection and systemic discrimination
Credibility_Assessment: Not explicitly addressed, but implied concern over dismissal of applicant's fears based on lived experience
Decision_Outcome: Refugee claim rejected based on presumed availability of state protection in Mexico
Outcome: Application allowed; decision quashed; case remanded for reconsideration by different Board member
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of refugee claim rejection
Remedy_Sought: Quashing of decision and order for reconsideration
Legal_Standard_Applied: Claimant must prove inability or unwillingness of home country to provide protection; state protection presumed unless rebutted
Decision_Rationale: Board erred by not addressing contradictory evidence about the effectiveness of state protection, particularly regarding police response and discrimination against homosexuals

Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Involvement in a robbery incident with potential use of force or threat
Crimes.Mitigating_Factors: Applicant provided explanations in response to allegations
Crimes.Criminality_Severity: High (serious offense involving violence or threat)
Crimes.Risk_Assessment: High risk due to alleged violent criminal behavior
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Incident report, applicant’s response
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Deemed credible enough to support denial
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant's explanations considered but not sufficient to overcome allegations

Crimes.Governing_Law: Aeronautics Act, Canadian Transportation Accident Investigation and Safety Board Act
Crimes.Application_Facts: Denial based on alleged involvement in 2007 bank robbery
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Allegation of lack of procedural fairness
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court jurisdiction over judicial review
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Details of 2007 robbery incident, applicant’s written response
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant’s credibility assessed through submitted explanation
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Applicant informed of allegations and given opportunity to respond; no hearing required

Crimes.Crime_Name: Possession of proceeds of crime over $5000
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Procedural fairness in administrative decision-making
Crimes.Governing_Law: Proceeds of Crime (Money Laundering) and Terrorist Financing Act
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Incident of robbery linked to proceeds; applicant allowed to respond
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Applicant’s explanation evaluated but not accepted
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Procedural fairness requires notice and right to respond
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: 2007 bank robbery incident and connection to proceeds
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Applicant provided explanations regarding the incident
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Documentary and incident-based evidence
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 8 of the Aeronautics Act and associated regulations

Governing_Law: IRPA, Section 87(1), Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Application_Facts: Mr. Porto Turizo applied for permanent residence based on work experience under NOC 0711; his duties aligned with the lead statement and main duties of NOC 0711
Procedural_Issue: Failure to provide adequate reasons for refusal
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Officer did not explain why employment letter was insufficient
Outcome: Judicial review granted; decision set aside
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of immigration officer's decision
Remedy_Sought: Redetermination by another immigration officer
Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness standard
Decision_Rationale: The officer's refusal lacked sufficient justification; alignment of duties with NOC 0711 was not properly addressed

Crime_Name: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act Violation
Application_Facts: Applicant's refugee claim was dismissed due to credibility issues and lack of asylum claims in transit countries.
Procedural_Issue: RAD relied heavily on RPD's findings using 'reasonableness' language without independent assessment.
Burden improperly placed on applicant to rebut RPD's findings.
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure by RAD to independently assess evidence.
Credibility_Assessment: Credibility issues were central to the dismissal of the refugee claim.
RAD did not conduct its own credibility analysis.
Decision_Outcome: Refugee claim dismissed by RAD based on RPD's credibility findings.
Remedy_Sought: Reconsideration of the case by a different RAD panel.
Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness standard
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness standard was incorrectly applied; required independent assessment.
Decision_Rationale: RAD erred in law by failing to independently assess the evidence and instead deferring to RPD's findings.

Crimes.Risk_Assessment: Serious possibility of harm upon return
Crimes.Evidence_Sufficiency: Sufficient to rebut presumption of state protection
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not adequately considered by Refugee Protection Division

Crimes.Risk_Nature: Domestic violence with state complicity through inaction
Crimes.Evidence_Sufficiency: Sufficient to establish inadequate state protection
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Overlooked by decision-maker
Decision failed to address contradictory evidence

Crimes.Risk_Assessment: Objective basis for fear of life
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Enforcement gap in domestic violence cases
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Insufficiently weighed by tribunal

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of conclusion on state protection
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Failure to consider key evidence on police inaction
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On claimant to rebut presumption of state protection
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Flavia Cherry’s evidence dismissed without justification
Crimes.Legal_Rule: State protection must be effective and accessible
Crimes.Legal_Framework: IRPA s.96, s.97; case law on gender-based claims
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Did not justify dismissal of contradictory evidence

Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Inadequate state protection for victims of domestic violence
Crimes.Legal_Framework: International human rights standards, gender-based persecution guidelines
Crimes.Targeted_Group: Female victims of intimate partner violence in Saint Lucia
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Systemic failure to protect vulnerable women
Crimes.Perpetrator_Entity: Private actor (partner), state as passive enabler
Crimes.Victim_Basis: Membership in particular social group (women unable to leave abusive relationships)

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to Provide Necessaries of Life (Potential)
Crimes.Violation_Type: Denial of refugee protection due to flawed state protection assessment
Crimes.Application_Facts: Ms. James fled domestic violence in Saint Lucia fearing for her life
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Lawfully present in Canada as asylum seeker
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Failure to properly assess credibility and evidence
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Overlooked material evidence on systemic failures
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Insufficient reasoning in rejecting protective needs
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Well-founded fear of persecution or danger
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Presumed state protection without adequate analysis

Crime_Name: Immigration-related risk assessment and humanitarian claims
Application_Facts: Applicants claimed risk of persecution in Mexico and sought humanitarian grounds for staying in Canada
Procedural_Issue: Officer dismissed letters from family and professionals as 'not disinterested' without context
Failed to properly weigh evidence
Ignored contradictions in evidence
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to consider context of letters
Lack of proper weighing of evidence
Ignoring contradictions
Credibility_Assessment: Letters dismissed as not disinterested without sufficient justification
Relief_Sought: Stay in Canada based on risk of persecution and humanitarian grounds
Remedy_Sought: Re-assessment of PRRA and H&C claims by another Officer
Legal_Standard_Applied: Best interests of the child reasonably analyzed
Decision_Rationale: Decisions lacked justification, transparency, and intelligibility; flawed evidence assessment

Application_Facts: Applicant was absent from Canada for 171 days during the four-year period preceding the application, falling short of the required 1,095 days of physical residency
Residency_Compliance: Failed to meet 1,095-day physical presence requirement
Procedural_Issue: Inadequate reasons provided by Citizenship Judge; failure to explain calculations or consider all evidence
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Judge did not adequately address or analyze submitted evidence including ICES and OHIP records
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of citizenship denial
Remedy_Sought: New hearing before a different Citizenship Judge
Legal_Standard_Applied: Physical residence requirement of 1,095 days in four years
Decision_Rationale: Decision found unreasonable due to lack of justification, transparency, and intelligibility in the Judge's reasoning

Application_Facts: Manickan claimed refugee status but was rejected due to disbelief in his testimony despite relevant documentary evidence linking him to risks faced by Tamil males in Sri Lanka.
Procedural_Issue: Board dismissed claim based on incredibility without considering documentary evidence, violating legal standards.
Evidence_Used: Documentary evidence linking claimant to risks faced by Tamil males in Sri Lanka
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to consider relevant documentary evidence supporting the claim
Credibility_Assessment: Finding of incredibility made by the Board
Decision_Outcome: Original decision set aside; application for judicial review allowed
Outcome: Case remanded for reconsideration by a new panel
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of the Board's decision
Remedy_Sought: Reconsideration of refugee claim with proper assessment of all evidence
Legal_Standard_Applied: Subjective and objective branches of the refugee test
Decision_Rationale: A finding of incredibility does not automatically disqualify a claim if other evidence supports both branches of the refugee test; omission of documentary evidence rendered the decision unreasonable.

Crimes.Crime_Name: Obtaining permanent residence by false representation
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Citizenship revocation based on fraudulent application
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether citizenship was obtained through false representation or concealment of material facts
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Defendant's claims were found not credible due to contradictions in evidence
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 10(2) and Section 18(1)(b) of the Citizenship Act
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: False information regarding nationality, education, employment, and fabricated persecution story
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Knowingly providing false information to obtain refugee status and permanent residence
Crimes.Proceeding_Type: Federal Court proceeding initiated by Minister under Section 18
Crimes.Application_Error: Misrepresentation of personal and biographical details
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Hearsay evidence regarding alleged involvement in genocide
Crimes.Legal_Standard: False representation or concealment of material circumstances under Section 10
Crimes.Application_Factor: Use of false identity and background to gain immigration benefits
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Declaration that citizenship was obtained by fraud
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Forged or falsified educational and personal documents

Crimes.Crime_Name: Obtaining Canadian citizenship by false representation
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 10 and Section 18(1)(b) of the Citizenship Act
Crimes.Application_Facts: False claims about nationality, birthplace, education, employment, and persecution history
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Refugee applicant turned permanent resident and citizen
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Complied with residency requirements but obtained status through fraud
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Proceedings conducted by default due to defendant’s non-participation
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court jurisdiction under Section 18 of the Citizenship Act
Evidence_Used: Official records from Rwanda and academic institutions
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient reliable evidence to prove war crimes involvement
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant deemed not credible due to multiple inconsistencies
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Citizenship declared obtained by false representation
Crimes.Outcome: Revocation recommended and allowed under law
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: False statements led to grant of permanent residence and citizenship

Crimes.Crime_Name: Obtaining Canadian citizenship by knowingly concealing material circumstances
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Citizenship revocation for concealment of material facts
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether material facts were concealed during immigration and citizenship process
Crimes.Outcome: Citizenship revoked due to concealment and misrepresentation
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Defendant’s narrative was inconsistent and unsupported by evidence
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Concealment of true identity and background, including possible genocide involvement
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Failure to disclose material information relevant to admissibility
Crimes.Application_Error: Omission of significant biographical and criminal history details
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Unreliable hearsay allegations of war crimes
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Knowingly concealing material circumstances under Section 10
Crimes.Application_Factor: Use of fabricated refugee claim to gain entry and status
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Submission of falsified personal and educational documentation

Crimes.Crime_Name: Obtaining permanent residence by knowingly concealing material circumstances
Crimes.Violation_Type: Concealment of material facts in permanent residence application
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 10 and Section 18(1)(b) of the Citizenship Act
Crimes.Application_Facts: False information on birthplace, citizenship, education, employment, and persecution claims
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Refugee applicant who became permanent resident
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Met formal residency duration but gained status improperly
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Deliberate concealment and fabrication to qualify as refugee
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Default judgment due to lack of defense from respondent
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of corroborated evidence on genocide participation
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant found not credible due to numerous falsehoods
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Permanent residence and citizenship deemed fraudulently obtained
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Deprivation order under Governor in Council
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Fraudulent basis of initial permanent residence invalidates subsequent citizenship

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Fraudulent acquisition of citizenship through deceptive means
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether citizenship was obtained by fraud, false representation, or concealment
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Defendant’s claims were discredited by documentary evidence
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Systematic misrepresentation of identity and experience to gain refugee protection
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Intent to deceive immigration authorities for status
Crimes.Application_Error: Falsification of educational and personal history
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Allegations of war crimes based on hearsay
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Fraud or false representation under Section 10
Crimes.Application_Factor: Fabricated persecution narrative leading to refugee status
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Declaration that citizenship was obtained fraudulently
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Use of forged or altered documents in application process

Crimes.Crime_Name: Misrepresentation under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Legal_Issue: Did the Member err by failing to consider the likelihood of applicants appearing for their refugee hearings?
Outcome: The Member erred by not considering refugee hearings in assessing flight risk. Case remitted for redetermination.
Application_Error: Failure to consider relevance of refugee hearings in flight risk assessment
Legal_Standard: Assessment of flight risk and alternatives to detention

Application_Facts: Applicants wanted in China for fraud, seeking refugee status in Canada
Procedural_Issue: Failure to consider ongoing proceedings in detention decision
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to consider active refugee claims as a factor in flight risk
Relief_Sought: Release from detention
Remedy_Sought: Judicial review
Legal_Standard_Applied: Assessment of flight risk and alternatives to detention
Decision_Rationale: Focus on removal likelihood without considering refugee hearings was unreasonable

Legal_Issue: Did the Member err by failing to consider the likelihood of applicants appearing for their refugee hearings as part of the flight risk analysis?
Evidence_Assessment: Member focused solely on removal likelihood
Legal_Rule: ID must assess flight risk and alternatives to detention, including upcoming proceedings
Grounds_for_Claim: Erroneous omission of relevant proceedings in flight risk analysis
Legal_Framework: IRPA and Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations

Crimes.Crime_Name: Membership in an inadmissible class under Immigration Act
Crimes.Violation_Type: Inadmissibility based on complicity in crimes against humanity
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant was a former Philippine army officer accused of participating in military operations involving atrocities
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Applicant for permanent residency in Canada
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Omission of prior exclusion as a Convention Refugee
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Testimony, documentary evidence on military unit conduct, credibility assessment
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: IRB found applicant's testimony not credible; assessment upheld as not patently unreasonable
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness standard for mixed questions of law and fact
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness; patent unreasonableness for credibility findings
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Credible evidence supported applicant’s complicity in crimes against humanity

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Immigration inadmissibility due to false statements
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether applicant misrepresented material facts in permanent residency application
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant's credibility undermined by contradictions and omissions
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Oral testimony, prior refugee claim record, IRB findings
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 27(1)(e) and (g) of the Immigration Act
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Failure to disclose exclusion as refugee due to alleged war crimes
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Materiality of omission regarding past refugee claim rejection
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to disclose adverse immigration history
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness of IRB's factual and legal conclusions
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: None identified – court found IRB considered relevant evidence
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Misrepresentation of material facts warrants deportation
Crimes.Application_Factor: Concealment of involvement in human rights abuses
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Not applicable – issue was omission and credibility, not forged documents

Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Alleged personal involvement in state-sponsored atrocities
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Participation in military operations resulting in unlawful killings
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: IRB finding of complicity upheld by Federal Court
Crimes.Government_Body_or_Authority: Immigration and Refugee Board (IRB), Federal Court
Crimes.Jurisdiction: Canada (Federal jurisdiction over immigration and refugee matters)
Crimes.Individual_Status_or_Claim: Former military officer seeking permanent residency
Crimes.State_Protection_Assessment: Philippine government forces were perpetrators, not protectors
Crimes.Risk_Factor: Systematic use of extrajudicial killings by state actors
Crimes.Credibility: Applicant’s denial not accepted; IRB found testimony inconsistent with evidence
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 27(1)(g) – membership in inadmissible class due to crimes against humanity
Crimes.State_Protection_Adequacy: Inadequate or actively harmful state protection
Crimes.Perpetrator_Entity: Philippine Army units during applicant's service
Crimes.Victim_Basis: Political opinion and suspected affiliation with opposition groups

Legal_Provision_Violated: Section requiring adequate notice in immigration proceedings
Application_Facts: CIC sent a letter on March 27 to the correct address via regular mail; applicant's consultant claimed non-receipt; no evidence provided on mail system unreliability
Residency_Compliance: Application denied due to non-submission of requested documents
Procedural_Issue: Alleged failure to ensure actual receipt of notice
Evidence_Used: Copy of the March 27 letter in file
Proof of mailing to correct address
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Applicant failed to provide evidence that the mail system was unreliable or that notice was not received
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of permanent residency application denial
Remedy_Sought: Quashing of CIC's decision and reinstatement of application
Legal_Standard_Applied: Procedural fairness - adequacy of notice
Decision_Rationale: Duty of procedural fairness met by proof of sending to correct address; no exceptional circumstances shown to require proof of receipt

Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration Act - Convention refugee definition, credibility requirements
Application_Facts: Applicant, an Angolan citizen, claimed refugee status in Canada based on fear of persecution; fled without documents; provided testimony with minor inconsistencies in dates and demeanor interpreted as lack of passion
Residency_Compliance: Not applicable – claimant was seeking entry/residence through refugee protection process
Misrepresentation_Element: Alleged inconsistencies in testimony and lack of documentation raised concerns, but no intentional misrepresentation found
Procedural_Issue: CRDD's credibility assessment relied on unreasonable grounds including cultural bias and lack of documentary evidence despite context of flight
Jurisdictional_Issue: Judicial review under subsection 82.1 of the Immigration Act
Evidence_Used: Oral testimony, lack of supporting documents, perceived emotional demeanor
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of documents due to fleeing circumstances, minor date inconsistencies
Credibility_Assessment: CRDD doubted credibility based on lack of documents, inconsistent dates, and perceived lack of passion; court found these reasons patently unreasonable
Outcome: Judicial review granted; CRDD decision set aside
Relief_Sought: Recognition as a Convention refugee, protection from removal
Remedy_Sought: Redetermination of refugee claim by a different panel
Legal_Standard_Applied: Well-founded fear of persecution on Convention grounds
Decision_Rationale: Credibility findings must be reasonable and based on substantial evidence; minor inconsistencies and lack of documents do not undermine claims when context is considered; cultural biases must not influence assessments
Authority_Responsible: Canadian Refugee Determination Division (CRDD), Federal Court on judicial review

Application_Facts: The Seiffert family had extensive international travel but established businesses and residences in Canada.
Residency_Compliance: Did not meet the 1095-day residency requirement due to absences
Procedural_Issue: Breach of natural justice during oral hearing, failure to properly analyze residency connections
Evidence_Used: Businesses and residences established in Canada, travel history
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Judge focused on absences rather than Canadian connections, failed to apply Re Koo and Re Papadogiorgakis factors
Outcome: Seiffert family deemed to meet residency requirements and entitled to Canadian citizenship
Relief_Sought: Review of Citizenship Judge's decision
Remedy_Sought: Grant of citizenship based on proper assessment of residency
Legal_Standard_Applied: Three years of residence in Canada within four years preceding application under Section 5(1)(c)
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness, with consideration of natural justice
Decision_Rationale: The Citizenship Judge erred by focusing on absences and failing to assess the applicant's overall connection to Canada, resulting in a reviewable error.

Application_Facts: Applicant claimed refugee status based on political persecution
Procedural_Issue: Board used conflicting standards ('balance of probabilities' and 'serious possibility') in decision-making
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Unclear application of the correct legal test
Decision_Outcome: Refugee status denied by the Board
Outcome: Board's decision quashed, new hearing ordered
Relief_Sought: Judicial review
Remedy_Sought: Overturning of Board's decision, new hearing
Legal_Standard_Applied: serious possibility of persecution
Standard_of_Review: Correct legal test under section 96 of IRPA
Decision_Rationale: Board erred in applying the correct legal test for determining refugee status

Legal_Issue: Can the Refugee Protection Division (RPD) determine a state-issued identity document is inauthentic based on physical anomalies without expert evidence?

Application_Factor: Authenticity of identity documents central to refugee claim

Document_Fraud: Mismatched professions, erased signatures, stapled photos, and other alterations indicating forgery

Legal_Rule: s. 49(4) allows partial forfeiture at Officer's discretion
Key_Evidence_Considered: Testimony regarding Officer's understanding of discretion

Evidence_Assessment: Claimant's testimony on forced marriage and persecution in Cameroon
Decision_Outcome: Refugee claim rejected due to lack of credibility and existence of internal flight alternative
Burden_of_Proof: On the claimant to establish a well-founded fear of persecution
Credibility_Factor: Inconsistencies in claimant's narrative, implausibility of allegations
Legal_Rule: Standard of reasonableness applies to RAD decisions
Grounds_for_Claim: Persecution due to forced marriage in Cameroon
Outcome_on_Merits: Claim dismissed by RPD, upheld by RAD
Legal_Framework: IRPA, Charter of Rights and Freedoms, Federal Courts Act
Defendant_Response: RPD found lack of credibility; RAD deferred to RPD findings
Legal_Provision: Section 96 of IRPA, Section 72 of IRPA
Authority: Refugee Protection Division (RPD), Refugee Appeal Division (RAD), Federal Court of Canada

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the CRDD breached procedural fairness by not allowing Gabor to explain discrepancies in the conscription notice
Crimes.Governing_Law: Principles of procedural fairness in administrative decision-making
Crimes.Outcome: Judicial review allowed, decision quashed, case remitted to a new panel
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: CRDD questioned Gabor's credibility due to the later-dated conscription notice without giving him an opportunity to respond
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Conscription notice
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Refugee claim involving authenticity of military conscription document
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Authenticity and timing of the conscription notice
Crimes.Proceeding_Type: Administrative hearing before the CRDD, followed by judicial review
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to provide procedural fairness by not addressing document discrepancy with applicant
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Potential explanation for discrepancy in document date
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Procedural fairness in administrative proceedings
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness, with consideration of procedural fairness
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Alleged misrepresentation through inconsistent border or identity documents

Crimes.Evidence_Type: Call-up notice
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Gabor's credibility negatively impacted due to unexplained document discrepancy

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the CRDD breached procedural fairness by failing to allow Gabor to explain discrepancies in the conscription notice
Crimes.Governing_Law: Duty of fairness in administrative decision-making
Crimes.Outcome: Federal Court quashed the CRDD’s decision and remitted the case to a new panel
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: CRDD assessed Gabor as lacking credibility based on document date without seeking clarification
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Conscription notice
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Refugee protection claim involving alleged document inconsistency
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Timing and authenticity of the conscription notice
Crimes.Proceeding_Type: Refugee determination proceeding and subsequent judicial review
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to notify Gabor of concerns about document authenticity and allow response
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Possibility of legitimate explanation for document date discrepancy
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Procedural fairness in administrative law
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Inconsistent official document affecting claimant's credibility

Legal_Issue: Whether defendants can amend their defense to challenge the validity of plaintiff's trade-marks based on misstated first use dates
Evidence_Assessment: Misstated first use dates on trade-mark registration
Burden_of_Proof: Defendants bear burden to prove invalidity due to material false statements
Credibility_Factor: Plaintiff's accuracy in stating first use dates
Legal_Rule: Amendments must arise from substantially the same facts unless no limitation period applies; false statements may invalidate trade-marks under Section 18
Standard_of_Review: Appellate review of discretion to allow amendments
Grounds_for_Claim: Trade-mark infringement by defendants; counterclaim for invalidity based on misrepresentation
Key_Evidence_Considered: Dates of first use claimed in trade-mark registration
Defendant_Response: Sought to amend defense and file counterclaim challenging validity of trade-marks
Remedy_Requested: Permission to amend defense and counterclaim
Outcome: Amendment permitted; no prejudice found; interests of justice served

Legal_Issue: Is the Immigration and Refugee Board's decision regarding the internal flight alternative (IFA) in Abuja reasonable given the applicant's circumstances?
Outcome: The application for judicial review is allowed, and the matter is sent back to a newly constituted Board for redetermination.
Legal_Provision: Section 72 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Basis_of_Claim: Refugee protection due to FGM, abuse, trafficking, lack of family support, and psychological trauma
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Applicant's vulnerabilities including trauma, illiteracy, lack of education, and no family support
Evidence_Ignored: Psychological state, personal vulnerabilities, lack of support systems
Legal_Standard: An IFA must be viable and reasonable for the specific claimant considering their psychological and personal situation
Application_Factor: Severe trauma, FGM, forced prostitution, human trafficking, disownment

Legal_Issue: Is the Immigration and Refugee Board's decision regarding the internal flight alternative (IFA) in Abuja reasonable given the applicant's circumstances?
Legal_Rule: An IFA must be viable and reasonable for the specific claimant considering their personal situation
Grounds_for_Claim: Fear of persecution, trauma, human trafficking, FGM threats
Key_Evidence_Considered: History of trafficking, forced prostitution, psychological stress, lack of education and family support
Legal_Provision: Section 72 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act

Violation_Type: Failure to recognize viability of internal flight alternative for vulnerable claimant
Application_Facts: Applicant suffered human trafficking, FGM threats, disownment, illiteracy, and emotional/physical stress
Procedural_Issue: Inadequate consideration of vulnerabilities in IFA assessment
Evidence_Used: Personal history of abuse, lack of support, psychological condition
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Board failed to consider applicant’s vulnerabilities
Relief_Sought: Refugee protection
Remedy_Sought: Redetermination by a new Board
Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness standard for IFA
Decision_Rationale: IFA not viable due to claimant’s extreme vulnerability

Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Grounds_for_Claim: Past trauma, forcible confinement, abuse, fear of persecution
Risk_Factor: Trauma, illiteracy, lack of family support
Legal_Provision: Section 72 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
State_Protection_Adequacy: Insufficient protection from harm in Nigeria
Risk_Nature: Persecution based on gender and past victimization
Victim_Basis: Gender, past exploitation, lack of support

Victim_Status: Female refugee claimant with history of trauma
Risk_Assessment: High risk if returned to Nigeria
Targeted_Victimization: Women subjected to sexual exploitation and FGM
Targeted_Individual: Female survivor of trafficking and abuse

Dispute_Type: Interpretation of inadmissibility grounds under immigration law
Legal_Issue: Whether medical officers erred in concluding excessive demand on social services under s. 19(1)(a)(ii)
Outcome: Judicial review allowed; decision invalidated and referred back for reconsideration
Evidence_Type: Medical assessment, evidence of ability to work in sheltered workshop
Legal_Provision: s. 19(1)(a)(ii) of the Immigration Act, s. 22(e) of the Regulations
Basis_of_Claim: Potential reliance on social services due to mental disability
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Failure to assess whether services would limit access for Canadians
Application_Error: Failure to apply s. 22(e) requirement regarding service accessibility and impact on citizens
Assessment_Standard: Whether social services would cause excessive demand and impede access for Canadian residents
Evidence_Ignored: Samuel's ability to work in a sheltered workshop and lack of evidence on service limitations
Legal_Standard: Proper interpretation and application of statutory provisions in immigration inadmissibility decisions
Application_Factor: Nature of social services required and their availability
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness or correctness (implied by judicial review context)

Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Excessive demand on health or social services due to son's cerebral palsy
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Immigration officer's decision upheld as reasonable
Crimes.Institutional_Action: Refusal of family admission based on health inadmissibility
Crimes.Individual_Status_or_Claim: Applicant seeking admission with family member
Crimes.Risk_Factor: Potential excessive burden on public health and social services
Crimes.Credibility: Applicant's financial plan deemed insufficiently credible
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Economic and systemic strain on public services
Crimes.Victim_Basis: Discrimination based on disability and family status

Crimes.Crime_Name: Excessive demand on health or social services
Crimes.Application_Facts: Son has cerebral palsy; applicant provided financial plan lacking specificity and credible arrangements for medical care
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Applicant as parent of child with disability
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Failure to meet admissibility requirements for permanent residency
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of credible, specific evidence regarding long-term care funding and service access
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Plan relied on weak assumptions; deemed not credible by officer and court
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Certification of general importance, reversal of decision
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Excessive demand on health or social services
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Officer reasonably concluded that the son’s condition could cause excessive demand on Canadian services
